review_title: Don't be Next: Negligence Empowering Egregious Cycle of Hiring/Firing without Cause in College of Health
pros: The leadership for administration at the Lehigh University College of Health (COH) is an abomination that has been empowered to create a toxic culture of hirings and firings before the end of the institution's unusually long probationary period for new-to-the-institution employees. At different times during the span of only 1.5 years the same leadership for administration has been allowed to hire five full-time staff members from outside of the institution. Each time they have abused the policy to get rid of the person before hiring the next, creating a revolving door of unjustly dismissed personnel. To begin the cycle, COH leadership for administration hired two staff members, then six months later fired them both. A few months afterward, the same leadership for administration hired another person and fired them six months later. And in another few months, yet again, two more people were hired and fired six months later by the same leadership for administration. The COH leadership for administration has fired every person they have hired from outside of the institution while only justifying it by the probationary period. They are not required to provide a performance improvement plan and do not have to substantiate any of their blatant mischaracterizations of the employees' work. An institution with ideal oversight would wonder "how can administration directors hire so many employees and then fire them in that period of time? They are the ones hiring them, so how can they misfire so many times?" The obvious answer is leadership is the issue and not the hires. Yet, the institution through the highest of COH leadership and University HR have done nothing to stop this cycle. Each staff member hired and set up for failure has communicated to HR about the issues. And yet, the leadership for administration is allowed to relist for positions, only to hire someone to fire them in another six months. The leadership for administration takes people away from secure jobs for promise of an opportunity to build a new college, only to take away the livelihood that their families rely on. They've derailed and negatively impacted thriving careers by thoughtlessly putting gaps in resumes and causing them to have to defend themselves in future interview processes. The only staff member safe from the leadership for administration has been a person who has been referred to openly as a "best friend outside of the university;" someone who this leadership for administration has brought with them from department to department across the university. Only staff from inside the university are protected because the leadership for administration is unable to fire them without going through a true process for dismissal. For those who are hired from the outside, the leadership for administration never has any valid reasoning, and a true process would never result in the employee being let go. Instead, they rely on the probationary period to justify narcissisms and playing God with people's careers and lives. If you are looking at any open positions for staff in the Lehigh University College of Health, please, please run the other way. If not, you will almost certainly be forced to six months later.
cons: A perverse cycle of hiring and firing staff members from outside of the institution without cause. The probationary period is used over and over again.

pros:
I was a PhD student from 2010 to 2014 in the Industrial Engineering Dept.
1- Social atmosphere and minority life: I am a non-American minority. The graduate life office puts together tons of programs where graduate students get together. Of course, there are more Indians and Chinese (I am from neither of those countries), but there are a lot of people interested in knowing about other countries. I never felt isolated.

2- Research quality: Of course it depends on your advisor. Mine was great and knowledgable. There are many well-known professors in the IE department. 

3- Salary: I was a TA for the most part. The pay was enough for normal life expenses + travels within the US and occasionally outside the US. For conference attendance money, it totally depends on your advisor's budget. 

4- Great focus on LGBTQ issues. I attended several workshops around these issues.

5- The health center: Great staff but limited care.
cons:
The school does not have a big name in general, but the quality for a PhD depends largely on individual departments and advisors.

In terms of the social events, the IE department has a rather tough atmosphere. Not much social activities at all.

review_title: No longer a rewarding place to work for staff.
pros: Depends entirely upon which faculty members you happen to work for.
cons: In the first 4-5 years of my employment at Lehigh it was a very challenging and rewarding experience. I did not mind the lower pay compared to colleagues at other universities (and especially in industry) given that I was allowed much autonomy and my contributions were respected. Senior management (ie. faculty) can attain such level of authority and responsibility without necessarily needing or having to demonstrate competence to actually do such. Effectively Lehigh has become a very "corporate" workplace for staff. There is a growing gulf, what some here describe as a "caste" system, between the "elite" faculty and the "servant" staff.

review_title: Good opportunity at Small Business Development Center
pros: Learn and assist local small businesses with International Trade Development Program.  "Small" also applies to the size of the center and you will familiarize with most of the members.  Very respectful coworkers and great experience.

cons: I truly can't think of any significant cons. The office space in general is kind of small, as it is more of just a series of small personal offices, but no major complaints there.

review_title: Not a place to work for a woman!
pros: The campus is a beautiful setting  and the students are great to work with.
cons: Women are treated as second class citizens. They are not respected or promoted or paid for their jobs the way the men are. Very political environment and a real Old Boys network is alive and well.There are NO HR practices in place. Men can do whatever they want to you with no repercussions.

pros: Great organization to work for. While working at Lehigh I had the advantage of learning from my colleagues and peers. I was given the opportunity to apply  my professional experience toward the progression of the institution and acquired great skills and competencies.
cons: Honestly don't feel there were any within my time with the institution.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bethlehem, PA
pros:
Lots of opportunities for travel (often fully reimbursed).
Research intensive
Strong alumni network
Every resource you could ever need
Master's level stipend one of the highest in the country (dependent upon program)
cons:
Campus is divided and does not have a strong sense of community
A lot of social issues that the university is working to combat but has been largely unsuccessful

review_title: Lehigh's department of biological sciences is a positive work environment filled with smart and down to earth people.
pros:
A collegiate environment, sharing of reagents, equiptment, ideas and protocols.
A diverse group of investigators that merge different disciplines
cons: Many of the lab spaces are old and outdated, the temperature at season transitions is poorly maintained and the ventilation system is filthy.

pros: It was a great place to work at. I learned a lot about my current field, and I was living in the work place. Felt like an internship.
cons: The pay was low and there really is no advancement opportunities because you are only working there, almost as a requirement.

review_title: Lack work/life balance and no room for advancement
pros: multiple options for health and insurance benefits, domestic partner benefits/recognition, tuition, sense of community, many talented colleagues
cons: university job title structure/hierarchy is limiting, exempt staff who teach not compensated additionally, some ineffective faculty, some students expect good grades for sub-par work

review_title: Great opportunity as a stepping stone
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Beautiful campus and great team to work with. Great international network and a global and committed approach towards employer benefits.
cons: Could go greener and leaner. Not a great number of postdocs hence limited networking and common forum opportunities. Lab infrastructure (not group/research specific)  could do with a fair overhaul and improvement.

review_title: Basically a way to pay you stipend
pros: The research assistant job is basically created to pay my stipend. I really do not need to do anything other than my usually PhD research and work towards my degree. However, this might not be true for all advisors.
cons: You certainly do not get paid much by being a graduate student.

pros: Very nice town. People (professors, officials) are enthusiastic and always ready to help. Have a great reputation in NYC and Philly.
cons: Location is not as good. Inconvenient. Top tier of the Street does not come to campus to recruit. Extremely lack of resource to graduate students.

job_title: High Education College Administrator in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Good pay and benefits, pretty easy job, nice resources
cons: Lots of annoying things to deal with, higher administration makes terrible decisions and does it way too late in the game, lots of politics, most people are super liberal and not even remotely tolerant of moderately conservative thoughts and ideas, parents and students are extremely entitled.

pros: good experience.The environment is great for all the researcher. It is close to NY and other cities. Thus great.
cons: a little lazy. the motivation is not enough. because the work is too comfortable. Next step try another good competition.

review_title: It is what you make it
pros: Freedom to pursue whatever interests you, very flexible work hours (I went on vacation for 2 weeks and worked from my computer without anyone realizing), fun environment
cons: No one is there to push you, so if you slack off, you will get nothing out of the experience

pros: supervisor are nice and smart and he is willing to teach. as long as you are willing to learn, there are plenty of opportunities
cons: nothing I can really think of. Maybe salary is a bit low but, I'm just doing it as a student so nothing i can really complain

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bethlehem, PA
pros: over all, not so much work, no stress. Have medical insurance benefit. Good experience for graduate students, easy money to make
cons: Uneven workload, some TAs have like 10 hours workload each week, but some 25 hours. Break your time into pieces, you have to deal with all kinds of staff

job_title: Chief Executive Officer in Hellertown, PA
pros: Lehigh Culture and the experience of being able to work with a very dynamic and interesting student body
cons: None, I attended Graduate school in the College of Business and taught as an Adjunct Lecturer.  I enjoyed my time and had memorable experiences during this time.

pros: Flexible hours, wonderful experience of teaching. You are not asked a lot, and you are given your opportunity with enough guidance.
cons: Some fellow tutors slacking off discourages you from working harder. The system of timing in/out needs some reconsideration to fix the problem.

review_title: I love my lab at lehigh
pros: Advisors are mostly helpful and friendly.
cons: Graduate core courses are merged with undergraduate classes. Qual exams in bio Dept are challenging. This year they did redesign the exams. They support stipend only up to 5 yr graduste program

pros: Lehigh Mountaintop Program was such an amazing experience that I gained a lot. You are in charge of your project of which you and your faculty advisor proposed.
cons: No one actually evaluates performance at the end of the program

pros: My coworkers and labmates were respectful and always willing to troubleshoot problems when they arose in our work.
cons: Working on the Mountaintop campus, you will be both physically and socially disconnected from the rest of the university.

pros: good people to work with
cons: academic salaries in anything except engineering or business are uncompetitive; disastrous record in recruiting upper administration for over 15 years

review_title: Graduate school isn't supposed to be fun
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Really like my direct boss and those in my lab.
cons: Stubborn faculty can be childish and a pain t work with. Although easy to ignore them as long as I am not working under them directly

pros: Earned an experience to do projects with different companies, really learned a lot not only on applying to practical issues, also on business parts.
cons: it will be better if there is more project opportunities

review_title: Great place to work in Bethlehem
pros: Big community of workers in almost every field. Different departments  sometimes open for collaboration. Like working on a team.
cons: Not very good employer for young people or recent grads.

pros: It's a well known research university. The professors are pretty professional and qualified.
cons: You might spend the summer without any funding.

pros: Amazing area, very good research
cons: While it tries to increase diversity, the area is very segregated; On one block its beautiful, go down the next and you'll be a less reputable part of the city.

pros:
I was GA and Library Supervisor
Some office can be very welcoming, some not. Depends.
Great opportunity for students to gain $ and experience.
cons: Some office can be very welcoming, some not. Depends.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Faculty members are among the best in the world.
cons: As the professors work extremely hard, they expect the same from you, which can lead to working on the weekends frequently.

review_title: Don't work for the Controller's Office
pros: Stable employment with excellent education and medical Benefits
cons: The management of the place is moody, miserable and lacking direction.

review_title: Lehigh is a great school for interdisciplinary study
pros: varied course requirements, expanding student population
cons: some teachers are very old fashioned and give boring lectures

pros: Low stress and lots of free time
cons: The pay is low but you don't do much anyway so its not that bad

job_title: Student Technical Consultant in Bethlehem, PA
pros:
- Great student/ work balance
- Allows time to do homework during work
- Lots of resources available if you need help
cons: - Few hours available throughout the week

job_title: Taylor Gym Desk Attendant in Bethlehem, PA
pros: This work study was great because I as able to do homework and study while working as a desk attendant.
cons: I could've used more staff shirts.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Bethlehem, PA
pros: More opportunities to work with people from different background; Professors are really nice.
cons: If you work for a lab, it is too far away to be there.

review_title: Fantastic college for employees and students alike
job_title: Access Service Representative in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Great benefits package, professional yet casual atmosphere. Plenty of opportunities to engage with the campus community.
cons: None to speak of as such.

job_title: Assistant Director of Financial Aid in Bethlehem, PA
pros: flexibility, benefits, schedule, professional development
cons: Some cons are that they are taking away parking for staff in which you will be bused to your location.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Great study-life balance, and a lot of resources.
cons: The CSE department is not as strong as it used to be. The career fair is not that useful.

pros: beautiful campus, cheap rent, even the pay is low, u can still have a life
cons: small town, no fun, that's all.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Denver, CO
pros: Beautiful campus, wonderful people, Amazing teachers, Administrative stuffs are super helpful
cons: No permanent cafeteria in Mountaintop campus

pros: Lots of opportunities to work with different departments, professors and create an impact
cons: Institutional differences between student body and what administration would like the university to be

review_title: Definitely one of the best places to work in Lehigh Valley
pros:
- Work/life balance
- Benefits
- Respected institution
cons:
- Lack of diversity
- Silos
- Low pay

pros: Good tuition benefits. flexible hours for the most part
cons: people worked there for long time so it is hard to advance your career.

review_title: Great people all around. The people made the place.
pros: The people were wonderful. Everyone in my office was nice and supportive.
cons: I outgrew the job quickly

pros: relaxed environment to work and there are a lot of young people. i liked labs, buildings, and athmosphere
cons: pay level is not that satisfied

review_title: Great environment to start a career
pros:
Positive environment
Room for growth
Ability to take classes for free
Working with students
cons:
Long hours
Balancing work and school and personal life

pros: beautiful campus and very convenient for living
cons:
limited resources for doing experiment in electrical engineering.
lab equipment are out of date

pros: Professors are highly knowledgeable and great to talk to
cons: tuition is very expensive and housing is not that great

pros: free schooling that employees are encouraged to take part in
cons: hard to advance. Not a lot of movement as it's a smaller department

pros: Good attitude, friendly and professional environment
cons: Relatively low pay and a few jobs for students

job_title: Wood Shop Monitor in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Fair wages, great work environment, work/school balance is fair with flexible hours.
cons: Administration can be a bit slow moving.

pros: Great place to work at.
cons: Still a PhD student. Bad food and University itself doesn’t care much about graduate students.

pros: Smaller university, friendly people, professional environment
cons: Can be pretentious, tenured faculty easier to work with than non-tenured

pros: Great hours and equal pay.
cons: Some of the front office management can misconstrue what it actually takes to accomplish duties.

review_title: Great place to study, not a great place to work/live
pros: Good university, small enough to know almost everyone
cons: Bad neighborhood, not safe. Poor management.

pros: Covering the tuition fee in addition to the salary.
cons: Your experience largely depend on the professor you are working with.

stressful

pros: Good! I love  working here

pros: Great professors to work with; nice environment; nice paid;

pros: Excellent team, positive community, fantastic learning opportunities
